Spring loaded craft cutter attachment for RichRap's awesome QuckFit carriage.  It allows for the blade tip to be aligned with my Jhead extruder so there is no mucking around with Z stops and such when I switch over.  
This is a complete do-over from a previous attempt that was overly complex and worthless. Keeping it simple.

What you will need: 1 - Quickfit housing print 1 - Top plate print 1 - Collar print 3 - ~11mm springs from cheap "Bic Pencil #2 0.7mm" mechanical pencils. Mine are 3.5mm wide and 11mm +- 1mm tall uncompressed. 1 - Vinyl cutter blade holder that is around 11.5 mm diameter. ( http://www.ebay.com/itm/330651969471?ssPageName=STRK:MEWNX:IT&_trksid=p3984.m1439.l2649 ) *And some tweezers help to get the springs installed. It seems pretty straightforward but the order of assembly is important to prevent disassembly reassembly. First check that everything fits and file/sand if needed. Check the Top Plate to its slot, the vinyl to its hole. Check that the Collar print fits onto the tool(disassemble the tool for installation). Check that the springs fit it there holes. Assemble in this order. 1-install vinyl tool in its hole.
2-Slide the Collar onto the vinyl tool.
3-Push the Top Plate into its slot.
4- Fit the springs in with some tweezers.
5- Put the guts back in the vinyl tool. The idea is that you set the blade for the depth you want to cut, then let the flat nose drag around on the material. And you don't need to readjust the z-axis to change it out ever! The vinyl tool fits in snug but loose so there is no wobble. The springs give it some cushion from imperfections in bed levels and also holds the tool tight to the paper, vinyl, whatever.

description.text:
A simple easy-to-print Organizer.
My wife is happy about it! Update
Added OrgBoxB18: 18.5mm high. Update 2
Added OrgBoxTest.

• Print 1x OrgBoxB , 1x OrgBoxT and 4x DeltaRods.
  • Insert the DeltaRods into the OrgBoxB (with a small hammer).
  • Insert the OrgBoxT into the DeltaRods.
    • *) To avoid distortions print it with a brim of 2-3 mm. The brim can be removed using scissors. Slicer Settings:
    layer height = 0.25
    perimeters = 2
    nozzle diameter = 0.35
    filament diameter = 1.75
    brim width = 3
    perimeters extrusion width = 0.39 (no setting > calculated, therefore the vertical thickness is 4 lines * 0.39 = 1.56mm) Optimizing:
    Print 1x OrgBoxTest and 1x DeltaRod.
    If needed change the extrusion multiplier parameter (slic3r) or scale the DeltaRods, e.g. to 95%.

comments.text: It took me awhile to get it to fit snug but I scaled the rods X axis down 90% and brushed some acetone on them to get them to stick in the holes snug. :)

title: Bright Pi - Bright White and IR Camera Light for Raspberry Pi
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Bright Pi is the Raspberry Pi accessory you have been waiting for. Bright white and infrared illumination for your RasPi camera module. The Bright Pi is a breakout/add on board for the Raspberry Pi (can be used with other I2C devices too - Arduino etc.) which adds both visible bright white light and infrared illumination to the Raspberry Pi, for use with the Raspberry Pi camera module, the Pi NoIR camera module or for any other project which requires bright LEDs! Bright Pi plugs directly into the I2C interface on the Raspberry Pi, and is completely controllable via the command line, using Python and lots of other programming languages as well. The brightness of the LEDs is fully controllable using the onboard LED driver chip. Want to use colourful LEDs instead? Well there is certainly nothing stopping you. The Bright Pi will allow you to control any ~5v LEDs using the I2C interface on the Raspberry Pi, so you could substitute the provided LEDs with the colourful LEDs of your choice! The Bright Pi has M2 mounting holes, just like on the camera module and Pi NoIR and can therefore be mounted directly to the camera module using the screws and spacers provided. It also has been verified to work great with the camera mount kit from Pimoroni, as seen in some of the pictures on this page. The Bright Pi is the perfect accessory for any project which utilises either the Raspberry Pi camera module or the Pi NoIR but just needs a bit more light, in a small and lightweight package!
If you would like to purchase a full Bright Pi kit or find out more information you can do so from our website at http://www.pi-supply.com/product/bright-pi-bright-white-ir-camera-light-raspberry-pi/

This design features both surface mount and through hole parts. The easiest and cheapest way to get your hands on a Bright Pi kit is to purchase one from our website at http://www.pi-supply.com/product/bright-pi-bright-white-ir-camera-light-raspberry-pi/ This also has the added bonus that it comes with mounting hardware and stickers! We supply these with the surface mount components already attached as they are quite small parts and are not suitable for soldering by beginners but should be possible for people who have some decent soldering equipment and a bit of experience.
Should you wish to make one yourself, the PCB Gerber files, circuit diagrams, pinouts, parts lists and more are available in these downloadable files. They are being released under a CC BY-NC-SA (Creative Commons Attribution Non Commercial Share Alike) license. This means you can recreate the board for your own personal use (non commercial) and modify it as you see fit. If you do either of these things you need to attribute the original design to ourselves (preferably with a link back to here, or the product page on our website, making sure to state that the resulting modified product is not endorsed in any way by Pi Supply) and you need to share the resulting files under the same CC BY-NC-SA license. Full license terms can be found here - https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-sa/3.0/

This is to go on the intake side of the 30mm cooling fan used on the E3Dv6 hotend.  It provides a grill to protect the fan, as well as a duct to try to limit intake away from the print bed.  This should work fine for the intake, but I would probably not use it for the exhaust side.  
I have provided the OpenSCAD script for this.  It allows you to change the size of the screw holes, the height of the duct above the grill, the height of the screw standoffs, the diameter of the screw standoffs, and the thickness of the grill plate (plus anything else if you rework the script).  
The standoffs make this part work better with thing: 455071.  I had 25mm screws.  Using a 2.5mm standoff made the screws go right about 2mm through the one part of 455071 and into the other (0.5mm for a washer, 2.5mm for the standoff, 2mm for the grill plate, 10mm for the fan, 8mm for the first part, leaving 2mm for the second part).  That is just about perfect.  You can adjust the plate thickness or the standoff to accommodate something else, if needed.

If necessary, set the parameters in the OpenSCAD file, compile it and export the stl.  If using with thing 455071 and 25mm M3 screws, you can probably just use the included stl.  
I printed it out of ABS, but PLA should work.  If there is too much heat in that location for PLA, then the fan might not be long for this world.  I printed with 0.2mm layer height, 2 perimeters, 50% infill.  
Once printed, I just screwed the parts together.
Just a basic box to hold a Sherline machine vice.  It is a nice close fit.  Printed well.

description.text:
Kossel 250 V-Slot 3D Printer - DIY Kit Nothing quite captures the imagination like a Delta style 3D printer in action. The UltiBots Kossel 250 V-Slot is a fun kit to assemble and print from. It has a 250mm heated bed with an aluminum heat spreader and Kapton Heater. This kit uses a PG35L geared motor directly mounted to the effector. Our Micro Extruder is compact, lightweight, and proven. It is unlike Bowden Tube style exctruders because the filament is fed directly into the HotEnds J-Head. Together with V-Slot extrusion and wheels this kit is straight forward and less complicated to build compared to many FFF 3D printers. Visit http://www.ultibots.com for Kossel 250 V-Slot, Mini Kossel V-Slot, MendelMax & UltiMax Kits, Printed Parts, Delta Components, Filament, Electronics, and More... Most current STLs are found here https://github.com/UltiBots/K250VS
See more of UltiBots Designs at http://www.thingiverse.com/UltiBots/designs

K250VS Build Guide and more... https://drive.google.com/file/d/0BzrtGXsdA6D8cVNOYmlGbm1oZlU/view?usp=sharing K250VS BOM is located here https://drive.google.com/folderview?id=0BzrtGXsdA6D8eThHX0ZKT0cwSjg&usp=sharing

description.text:
IMPORTANT NOTICE:
This script is not working with Processing 3, you have to use Processing 2.2.1!

This is a remix of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:29785. My modifications:
  • generates a PCB layout similar to the MK2a heat bed which is available at http://www.reprap.org/wiki/PCB_Heatbed
  • option to include wires for a thermistor
  • creates an SVG file instead of an Eagle board
    • UPDATE Sep 12, 2014:
  • added option to define package size of SMD thermistor used; suitable SMD soldering pads will be generated in this case
    UPDATE Nov 14, 2014:
  • fixed calculation of wire resistance

To generate your PCB heat bed layout
  • start your Processing 2 IDE (download from https://processing.org) and open HeatBedSVG.pde. IMPORTANT: the script is not working with Processing 3 or later, you need Processing 2.2.1!
  • set size of the board (h, w) and heated area (heatWidth, heatHeight)
  • set the voltage you want to run the heat bed with (voltage)
  • play with wire width and spacing to get the resistance required for your purpose (linewidth, traceSpacing, resistorPads). If your board is not completely filled, try different values for resistorPads
  • if you would like to have thermistor wiring included in the generated layout, set thermistor = true and modify the thermistor wire settings as you please
  • run the sketch; you will see the calulated resistance in the Processing window, the resulting heatbed.svg is written to your sketch directory

I had this colorful cabinet that was custom made for the kids room. The knobs made by the carpenter kept getting loose and breaking. On top of that they were not very aesthetic.
We endured 6 years with this knobs getting loose and exposing the screw which worry us because that was the room for our kids play in.
Some months after I bought my Afinia it hit me. " - I can make one knob out of ABS plastic!!"
It took three tries, the third one was perfect. It screwed on the same wood screw tight enough that the plastic sticks to the screw and don't loosen up.
And I even had the same basic colors that the cabinet had, so I printed some of each color and it couldn't be more perfect!
It was the first time that the 3D printer solution beaten anything I could have bought in a store! (for me at least)

Anyone with a 3d printer likes showing them off, especially if they can print something the other person wants. So there are lots of Free Print tokens of various kinds on Thingiverse. This one is designed to to be customized for a specific person. Hence "Blank". The back side is indented to match the front side so you can put whatever you want on the back side. This can be printed without supports. It has been signed so even relatively long strings (i.e. - three or four names() will be legible on low-quality printer.

Edit the .skp file in SketchUp to add text to the blank side. Use the 3d-text tool, and extrude the text 1mm. A short first name works really well. Three lines of text for longer names is legible, but you can't say much more than that.  
Print it at the best vertical resolution you can get.

title: Monoprice Dual Extruder 3D Printer Y Axis Motor Mount

description.text:
This thingy is a replacement part for the Monoprice Dual Extrusion 3D Printer. It can also be used on the Makerbet Replicator 2. It replaces the flimsy bracket that holds the Y-asix motor on the back right side of the frame that drives the print head front to back.
My factory bracket fell apart during a print job. I'm fortunate to have two 3D printers so I design and printed a replacement. The redesigned part is beefier. The holes are in the proper place so it's an easy repair job once you are able to print this model. Of course if all you have is a broken printer, then you can't print this part. Contact me at kent.roller google mail and I'll send you a printed one. Also check out my youtube video for more details and contact info. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=24W1xOPrz5U
DON'T MAKE AND USE THIS IN YOUR PRINTER WITHOUT ADDING A HEATSINK/FAN TO THE STEPPER MOTOR. Stepper motors get very hot and can deform PLA and ABS plastic. I used this bracket after printing it in PLA and it worked fine until heat from the motor warped the bracket.

comments.text: You know, you could easily just reuse the factory brass fittings.  All you need is a soldering iron and you can extract the factory brass mounts, and then insert them into the replacement.  If you find your screws keep backing out after that, enter blue Loctite!
comments.author: TheMakerRob

comments.text: Good point MakerRob.  I didn't think to reuse the brass nuts.  It wouldn't have been hard to mod the model with receiver pockets, but I was in a hurry to get the printer going again and settled for pilot holes for using sheet metal screws.  I don't know if I mentioned this, but a PLA bracket isn't ideal in the first place because the stepper motor gets hot enough to deform the bracket.  I had to further modify the whole hack by adding a cooling fan to the motor.  Monoprice eventually sent me half a dozen new brackets.  In a pinch my bracket keeps you going.
comments.author: TheMakerRob

comments.text: How do you intend for us to thread the mounting/tensioning holes?  Are you using the machine threaded factory screws or something else?
comments.author: kda406

comments.text: I first used the factory machined threaded screws and they worked, but they did loosen a little.  If you use them, apply Locktite.  On the second version of the bracket I used #4 x3/4" sheet metal screws and the bracket held much tighter.  Obviously a sheet metal screw will bite into the plastic better than the factory sheet metal screws.
comments.author: kda406

comments.text: Why don't you put in some nut traps like is commonly done?  Then you could drop in a pair of appropriate nuts that fit the stock machine screws.  These hold very securely, and with a drop of threadlocker, never let go.

title: Rope pole hook
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I want to be able to position some ropes lassoed up in trees when there isn't a branch available for making a tarp canopy while camping. This hook should be able to push a lasso up a trunk, and the hook portion should be able to grab the loop end to pull it down. The hook screws on to a standard broom stick or paint roller thread (I think ACME 3/4-5). I'm using a 5m extendable pole from a Costco snow rake, but it will fit on any pole like this one: http://www.amazon.com/Mr-Long-Arm-3212-Extension/dp/B00004YUPO/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1410223855&sr=8-2&keywords=extendable+pole

The two pieces in polehook.stl are all that is needed.  The others are original inputs or intermediate files in case you want to modify it.  
The hook portion is printed horizontally so layer separation won't lower pulling strength on the hook.  No support is needed.  I glued the two pieces together with ABS dissolved in acetone, then painted that glue over the outside of the round piece to increase inter-layer strength.  
The hole was meant for a 4mm bolt, but do to a screw up while cleaning it up with a drill bit, I actually finished mine by drilling the hole out to 5/16ths, printing 5/16ths x 22mm pin, and gluing that in. I actually like this better and recommend it.  If you do that, print your pin horizontally on the bed so that the layers don't shear when used as a pin.

This is a project that I made for my history teacher. It represents what I think it means to be an American.

First I drew the arches and the wings on illustrator. Then I placed the names of twenty great Americans on each of the feathers. Then I found one picture of each of the Americans, live traced it and placed it on the arches. I then printed everything out on different colored acrylic using a laser cutter. After that I made a base and rasterized it so that the two arches and the eagle could attach better to the base. Finally, I glued everything together using acrylic glue.

description.text:
A 3d printable sight for a recurve bow. Designed to be assembled with screws from local hardware store and 3D printed parts.
This is still a work in progress. Version 2 is being printed this week and will be tested on Wed (9/10/2014). Will update when I see how it turns out. V2 uses the pin sight from v1.

This is a work in progress. I tested this version over the weekend. These are the results that I have found so far.
  • Not stiff enough. The arm vibrated side to side.
  • There was a dead zone where you can't set the pin sight.
  • It is way to time consuming to adjust the sight. The sight has to basically be taken apart to adjust.
    On my bow the sight attaches to the riser with 10-24 screws.
    The pin sight is designed based on this design (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:150680). I adjusted the size of the hole to fit a 10-24 screws. It tore slightly when the 10-24 screw was inserted.
    The next design will be designed to allow for easier sight adjustment.

I may have gone a bit overkill with Version 2.  It is definitely going to be stiffer.  It may be more than needed.  Will shoot it tomorrow night (9/10/2014) and see how it goes.  This version is adjustable without dismantling.   The slider doesn't quite fit.  I would wait for Version 3.

One problem I had was adhesion to the surface at the edges.  I will replace the tape next round and see if that helps.

author: ponsmeister

title: Makerbot Replicator 2x Filament Fan Duct w/Magnets!!

description.text:
A dual fan duct for cooling filament for the Makerbot Replicator 2X. This version is modified to attach via 1/8" x 1/16" magnetic discs.  
I got tired of needing to attach the fans, cooling fins, fan guards, and filament fan duct all at the same time with another design so I modified this one to make it easier to attach and remove.

You will need 4 screws M3x14 or M3x16 to attach the active cooling fans.
You will also need 4 1/8" x 1/16" neodymium magnet discs. I highly recommend having a bunch of these on stock because magnets are cool, awesome, and sometimes very useful. You can find a pack of 100 for pretty cheap at Amazon.
I'll update once I print it out for myself and try it.

remixed_from.author: cfeniak
remixed_from.title: Direct Drive Bowden Extruder for 20 mm extrusion

title: Direct Drive Bowden Extruder; MK8 version

description.text:
Direct Drive Bowden Extruder for mk8 pulley
-simple, open, & compact
-easy to clean and adjust
-mounts with two M5 bolts at 20mm spacing
-designed to be drilled out for 1.75 or 3mm filament
-designed to be drilled out for a 5mm or 1/8 coupling
-designed for a mk8 pulley
-pulley is positioned close to motor base to reduce cantilevered load on motor shaft
-tensioning bolt catch is slotted to allow quick release functionality

Split and spread out idler arm before printing. Chose left or right version (mirrored). I've included on option for a mounting plate but you can easily design you own to fit your configuration.
BOM:
1x Nema 17 Stepper with high torque capability
1x MK8 hobbed pulley w set screw
1x pneumatic coupling
1x 625 bearing
3x M3-8mm bolt
1x M3-12 to 16mm bolt
1x M5-12mm bolt w nut
1x M5-30+mm bolt w nut & washer
1x spring to fit over M5 bolt
I used a knurled nut for the spring tensioner but a normal or winged nut could be used. Might want to print off something similar to:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:102153
Mounting bolts requirements will vary with your setup.

author: zach101

title: Fisher Price Peek Blocks Press & Go Train Battery door replacement

description.text:
This thing is a replacement battery door for a toy train (see thing name). My wife had the toy and was going to sell at a garage sale, but it was missing the battery door. It was a little tricky as the battery compartment has an O-Ring to keep water out and acid in if there is a leak. All of that is built into this door.
If you like my things, take a look at my blog. I have videos and information on 3d printing.
http://thekoalafarm.blogspot.com/

This object was modeled in Cubify Invent and printed on a FlashForge Creator. The slicer was ReplactorG 040-23 using SkeinForge as the slicer.
I printed exactly at this size without scaling. It is printed in ABS with the Chamber option checked. Printbed Heat starts at 120 degrees and drops to 70 at 5mm (which is taller than the part.
Didn't have any uplift or bridging issues.

author: zach101

title: 20mm Extrusion uses ONLY M3 hardware, screws and nuts

description.text:
I was upset to not find extrusion that was easy to piece together and needed special nuts to attach parts. Then I would find out the screw holes were for M4 or M5 screws, so I designed this.  
20mm, slots are designed to hold a 5.5mm M3 nut, and then screw down with M3 screws. Also the ends have holes in them to secure 20mm corner pieces with M3 screws.   
I will be uploading more sizes, and yes this only has slots on 2 sides, 4 sides printed along the x-axis, the 2 vertical sides would droop so I turned them into rounded edges to save material and time. I will be adding ways to connect these sometime soon.  
If someone wants a 4 sided extrusion with this design, I can upload one, you would have to print it vertical, my goal was to print horizontal since I enlarged my printer to about 10inches.

description.text:
This Thing is a remix of two existing Things.
The neck on this Cigar Box Ukulele is too big to fit on my Replicator2 bed. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:33835. So, I redesigned the geared head so that it slots into the neck in this Soprano Ukulele http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:162309. I also designed a sound hole cover. Sounds pretty good! Check out the video here: http://youtu.be/qa00a_EXgc4

• Print the neck, fretboard, and saddle from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:162309
  • Print the 2 gear_holder and four of the gear_post, tuner_gear and worm_gear from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:33835
  • Print the three files in this Thing
  • Use the neck pegs to glue and assemble the fretboard and neck
  • Assemble the gear, worm gear and posts and then drill holes to secure the gear holder with small screws.
    6.Optional: Cut a 3" square hole in the cigar box and glue in the sound hole cover
    I had to sand some of the tuner pieces. I also used a little Vaseline to lubricate the worm gears.

Remix of D&G Glasses found on Thingiverse. Adapted to use some existing lenses. Other changes include spacing adjustments to the hinge area and reinforcement around the hinge area on the frames. There is a slight outcropping at the bridge of the nose on the front of these frames, which necessitates a raft support on the machine I use.

I started by scanning the original glasses' lenses on a flatbed scanner, that gave me some pretty good measurements in 2 dimensions.   
I lack the measuring tools to get better precision, so in the spirit of rapid prototyping I quickly estimated an inner and outer tolerance by dropping an image of the scanned lenses into the model in SketchUp. I traced the image of the lens, and used the offset tool to copy the outline of the lenses and create a concentric inner shape that was small enough to mask all the inner edges of the lens.   
After removing the lens holes from the original model, I was left with a flat plane to drop my new lens outline on. At this point, I'm only working with one half of the model, because I know I'll need to make some adjustments after the first print.  
The push pull tool was used to carve the new lens hole into the old model (that had its lens holes removed), The inner outline was punched all the way through, while the outer outline was pushed only halfway into the model. After this, the first test was printed.  
The depth of the lens holders turned out to be too shallow on the first test. the lens also needed some resistance in the corners to avoid rocking around. I also needed to greatly increase the length and depth of the tab that would hold the lenses in. I increased the depth of the the entire frames portion of the glasses to accommodate the lenses better and bevelled the corners of the lens holes to fit the lens curvature better.  
The second test print was optimistic, so I printed both halves of the glasses (by mirroring my working 1/2 glasses model), and the stems. The stems came out well, but the parts of the hinges on the frames were too close together for the height of the part of the hinge on the stems, and the frames needed more help before they would hold the lenses.   
The third test had the added addition of more space for the stem hinge, and some reinforcement of the hinges on the frames. I also added a slight bump to the front of the glasses along the bridge of the nose so they wouldn't be completely flat on the front. This test was once again only a print of 1/2 of the frames, (I concluded that my previous optimism was overoptimistic.) The third test turned out great, so I mirrored the half model back to wholeness and printed the ones you see on my wife's face.   
Currently, the hinge is secured with part of a nail. I'll have to find the right screws to make it nice. For now, the old frames are holding up, but these will be ready for their lenses when they finally give out.  
I'm told they are blurry around the edges, so the next revision will have a bend in the bridge that causes the lenses to sit at the same angle as the previous frames.

I added a heatbed to my RepRap G3D (Prusa i3 design from Gadgets3D). The heatbed PCB was placed on top of a piece of cork and under Borosilicate glass. To hold these pieces together I created a set of “bed-clips”. The corner holes of the heatbed PCB perfectly aligned with my print bed so I was able to place a 2” bolt through the entire assembly. I printed knobs as well to ease the adjustment process. Lastly, the rear right clip includes a strain-relief support for my heatbed and thermocouple cables.
2016-01-24 Update:
  • Cleaned up Sketchup file.
  • added a captive nut clip to replace the "knobs", this makes adjustments easier

mutant brush is a design for a node and bars spatial structure. The nodes are digitally fabricated using laser cutter, and 3 mm 810 x 600 mm mdf sheets. The bars are put together with broom sticks. It can be used as an urban plug in to personalize, customize or appropriate urban space, but also in community or private patios, gardens, terraces, etc. The project has been developed in a cooperative process by a team composed by Fran FernÃ¡ndez Gallardo, Sergio Fernando GarcÃ­a de la Riva, Francisco MartÃ­n, Javier SantamarÃ­a with tutors Areti Nikolopoulou and Jose Perez de Lama at "The commons factory :: plug ins at santa ana" workshop, taking place october 18-25th 2010 at Absolut Lab [Fab Lab], Madrid, Spain The piece / construction system has been designed as site specific, but think it does have a very generic character. http://thecommonsfactory.worpress.com
http://www.absolut-lab.com

The cutting files are designed for 810 x 600 mm mdf sheets to be cut with a laser cutter. Joints in the files consider the material lost by the laser cut [Epilog Legend Ext 36x24 50 watts]. They should be tested to check if it works in the same way with the laser cutter you might be using. 
Nodes are made by three layer pieces. There are various different variations of nodes depending on whether they receive three, two, one or no bar. The direction of the structure changes connecting two nodes [see images]. Broom / brush sticks that we are using are aluminum, we think they are standard, at least in Spain.
[We will be uploading assembly drawings in the next days] 
Mutant Brush at this state has to be considered a beta. We should be uploading further developments.
Rhino and dxf files are cutting files.

title: Flexing battery holders with integrated spring

description.text:
For my electronic projects I often need battery holders of various size and for different number of cells: single, multiple cells in parallel or in series, or serial lithium-ion type cells with connectors for balanced charging between the cells. So the project here was to generate fully parametrized, printable battery holders for cylindrical cells of arbitrary size and number. The additional challenge for me was to have the battery sit firmly in the holder without the use of the metallic spring that is usually found at the minus pole. In this design the metallic spring is replaced by a flexible printed curled structure, which presses the contacts firmly to the battery. This plastic spring flexes about 1 - 2mm, which is just what's needed to comfortably insert and remove the cells. The contacts for the plus and minus pole can easily be made by a few windings of the uninsulated ends of the connecting wires. Each battery compartment contains are several holes to the outside as well ad to the neighboring compartments, through which connecting wires can be passed for easy configuring of parallel, serial or balanced-serial battery packs. Also, on the bottom of the case, there are longitudinal and traversal wire channels, which can be used for assing wires outside the case. Given that the printed plastic spring needs to be flexible, ABS is the material of choice here. Also, I use a some "ABS slur" (mixture of ABS and acetone) to cover and insulate the otherwise exposed outer part of the pole connectors.
In addition to the SCAD source file, I have added STL files for 1/2/3/4 cells of type AA, AAA, 18650(Li-Ion), as well as single cell versions for 18650P (protected Li-Ion), CR123A (aka 16340) and C (this one is untested yet, as I don't have any C-cell around here). Of course, you can also just use these battery holders without any wiring to serve as battery cases, for carrying your spare batteries around. But for this, you should also have a look at my battery caps... Update 2014-09-17: Upon request of user wohenzhuce I have also added STL files for 26650 type LiFePo Cells. These are still untested. They were produced in OpenScad with the call:
flexbatter(n=n,l=65.7,d=26.4,hf=0.72,shd=3,eps=0.28); Update 2015-04-10: Upon request of user h4wk3y I have now uploaded extra long versions (70mm) needed for some protected 18650 cells, these are named flexbatter18700xN.stl._ Update 2015-07-25: I just published a new version of this project which supports multi-cell compartments housing 2 or 3 cells in a row.

I printed these battery holders on my DIY box-frame Prusa i3 using a 0.40mm nozzle with 0.25mm layer height and 0.56mm extrusion width. By default, the thickness of the spring part is twice the extrusion width ew. If you have a significantly different extrusion width, for obtaining optimal spring strength, you might want to modify the eh and ew parameters in the SCAD file to fit your printer, and then rebuild all the STLs you need.

comments.text:
What version of OpenSCAD, and what slicer are you using?
Rendering to stl, then to gcode results in many unconnected points. My attempt to fix the stl found it needed to repair about 2000 faces ... and when sliced, leaves me with many missing parts and even whole layers. Viewing the exported stl file shows much transparency, missing walls and such. I'm using OpenSCAD version 2015.03-2 and am still examining what could cause this. Interesting is that OpenSCAD renders a correct view of the item, but seems to hickup exporting this to STL. Unfixed slicing to gcode results in a base layer which misses two springs (of 5, generating the 5x18650 case mentioned below)
I'm trying a different slicer now (skeinforge instead of slic3r) but my impression is that slicer doesn't cause the problem, instead it may hide or expose those to larger or lesser extent. (pre-slicer) admesh already reports problems with the STL.
comments.author: Bushmills

comments.text: I made some pictures of the resulting rendered files:
comments.author: Bushmills

comments.text: Currently I also use OpenScad 2015.3, but when I created the files it might have been an earlier version.  I use Linux width SFACT/skeinforge as slicer and so far I have not had any problems. But as you can see in some of the comments further down, there are other people who had problems similar to yours, which they they could resolve using STL repair tools such as netfabb.
comments.author: Bushmills

comments.text:
So I compared rendering results against a few more similar items, and the next I tried showed almost exactly the same problem. I went on comparing, and found that those two are the only implementations manifesting that strange behaviour.
Code didn't look like they were related to each other, but it's a reference point for determining the cause. Conversion of resulting STL to gcode with sfact/skeinforge resulted in a broken gcode gfile (depending on gcode viewer, I got either "error in file", or a segfault ...). It is my current impression that something triggers an obscure bug in OpenSCAD which results in creation of an incorrect STL files, which then propagates the error through slicers into gcode files.

comments.text: As is said in the text, I strip the insulation from the wire at the end and wind it around the "cylinders" at the + and - sides of the battery holder.  I usually strip about 10cm and do 5-6 windings, then cut off the remaining bare wire. Carefully study the parasolid or STL assembly file to familiarise yourself with the assembly.
Riser:
The riser is milled from 15mm Plexiglass (Acrylic/Perspex) I have nested the parts in the file called 'Milling layout no islands 2.STL'
The layout has been made to fit inside a 300x300 square in order to fit onto the bed of my Roland MDX40 so it should fit most 3 Axis milling machines.
Once machined, the limb bolt and limb pocket mounting holes can be carefully drilled by hand. Make sure the M8 Nyloc nut fits into the milled slot at each and of the riser and that the 8.5mm hole drilled for the M8 bolt lines up with the nut and the hole in the limb pocket. I used the finished limb pocket as a template to drill the holes. Once all the drilling has been done glue the riser sections together with CA glue. There are holes on each joining face for 3mm aligning dowels. I used 3mm dia carbon rod cut into 4 12mm pegs but you can use wooden dowels if you like since the are not structural at all. Sand the riser and paint if desired.
There are holes for a standard bow sight and a hole for a Gerber bolt to mount a standard bow rest. One thing I noticed in the prototype is that the side of the arrow shelf is not wide enough for my rest and if I was to do this again I would perhaps glue in an 8mm spacer between the riser sections just to make the shelf a little wider. (ie. Further from the centre of the bow)
Cams:
The Cams were 3D printed from ABS/Polycarbonate on a uPrint. If you don't have access to a high end printer then just mill them from polycarbonate and then hand cut the cable grooves on a router table or 4 axis cnc mill.
I have used the parallel cam system found on G5 Prime bows.I did this to try and keep the cams from leaning in the PVC pipe. It works pretty well but the limb pockets must be mounted dead straight!
Fasteners:
The cams are held together with M3x12 Socket head cap screws.
The limbs bolts are M8 x 40 SHCS and the limb pockets are M4 Countersunk screws.
The cam shafts are M4 x 50 Screws and I have used 4mm ID x 11mm OD x 4mm Wide bearings on either side of the limbs.
Limbs:
The limbs are made from schedule 40 PVC (1.25 inch) which is heat bent using a heat gun.
Nick from Backyard Bowyer demonstrates the technique here. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AKjcrEsYykE&list=PLD816DB6470FEE164
The process for the compound bow limbs is much simpler because you are just making two tapered pipes, not a whole bow, but the technique is the same.(I used two planks and LEGO blocks as spacers instead of making the jig like Nick does).
Once flattened cut the slot for the cams. Make sure to leave large radii in the corners to reduce stresses.
Refer to the parasolid files as a shape guide and you should be fine.
Stringing:
I used 2.5mm nylon rope for the string and cables and 1.5mm nylon string for the cam strings. I have included two diagrams showing the string lengths and their positions.
(DO NOT use the string position in the Parasolid file as a reference for stringing I just put them there for the render.)
To string the bow you need to compress the limbs. You could take it to a shop once you have made all your strings and put it in a proper bow press but this bow is pretty weak so this is not necessary unless you want to. I just tied a length of rope around the limbs and pulled it tight to pull the limbs together. This gave enough compression to string the bow and then I removed the rope carefully once done.
BE CAREFUL!! There is a lot of stored energy in a compressed bow!
Enjoy
DISCLAIMER:
This bow is intended as a target bow with low draw weight FOR KIDS, if you choose to scale to bow to adult proportions you do so at your own risk!
Do not aim this bow at anything living!!
Children should only use this bow under adult supervision!!
Be safe and responsible at all times, don't come crying to me when things go wrong.

description.text: I've been trying to reproduce the shape of the Glencairn whisky glass to print as wedding favours for a wedding in November.  I think I have finally nailed the shape.  The model in the photo is 0.7 scale, but the model is designed at the full size of a mini Glencairn.  For a fullsize glass, increase the print scale to 1.35.
If you want this to hold liquid, I recommend printing at least 1.2mm shell, 100% fill and 0.1 mm layer height. On the prototypes I have done, anything less caused seepage!

breed_ = greyhound
This is a replacement puck for a Bubble Hockey table.

I recommend printing at 100% infill with PLA. The puck must be heavy enough to pass through the table's scoring mechanism without getting stuck. PLA has a lower Rockwell hardness than the acrylic dome, while ABS is higher. ABS could scratch the dome during play, damaging an expensive and hard to find part. You may also want to sand the PLA smooth, for faster gameplay and to decrease wear on the play surface. There are a few types of bubble hockey pucks, and this one may not be compatible with your table. Example of a bubble hockey table:
http://www.amazon.com/Carrom-Super-Stick-Hockey-Table/dp/B000GWFELM

description.text:
anforme is a modular shading structure made out of laser cut 3mm mdf pieces, incorporating lighting devices and recycled plastic bottles for additional performance.
It can be used as an urban plug in to personalize, customize or appropriate urban space, but also in community or private patios, gardens, terraces, etc.
The project has been developed in a cooperative process by a team composed by VerÃ³nica CarreÃ±o Naranjo, Gabriela Massa Ascui and Silvia SÃ¡ez Iglesias with tutors Areti Nikolopoulou and Jose Perez de Lama at "The commons factory :: plug ins at santa ana" workshop, taking place october 18-25th 2010 at Absolut Lab [Fab Lab], Madrid, Spain
The piece / construction system has been designed as site specific, but we think it as well as a generic to be used in multiple circunstances

The main elements are cut with laser cutter out of 3 mm 810 x 600 mm mdf sheets. The press-fit connections in the files are dimensioned taking into account the material lost by the laser cut [Epilog Legend Ext 36x24 50 watts]. They should be tested to check if it works in the same way with the laser cutter you might be using.
Once the dmf parts are put together, the lighting and the bottles can easily installed, in the holes designed for it.
The structure is thought to be hanged form a tree or a lamp post.
Rhino and dxf files are cutting files.
[We will be uploading assembly drawings in the next days]

remixed_from.author: countspatula
remixed_from.title: 2X Extruder Upgrade for Raffle Alu-Dual Cooling Block

title: 2X Extruder Upgrade for Raffle Alu-Dual Cooling Block (Remix)

description.text:
This is a small change based on the fantastic work of both rmcniff (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:222667) and countspatula (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:256754).
Like countspatula I also recently installed my Carl Raffle Cooling block and hot end upgrade (http://shop.raffle.ch/). As the new cooling block has the hot ends positioned along the center line of the cooling block, a offset of around 3mm is required. The common approach is to add spacers between stepper and cooling block to get this done.
I however noticed that if I do that (use plastic spacers), the stepper motor get's even hotter and I end up having problems with certain filament through to that (the cooling block usually does not get very hot from the hot end alone) and hence I wanted to move the steppers back against the cooling block to help bring their temperature down.
What does the package come with:
  • All the files from countspatula's thing which are intended for a cooling block and hot end installation which is flush with the top of the hot end (no nut)
  • An additional base (_no cutout.stl) which features a recess for the standard nut that comes with Carls hot ends which will interfere with the original base if installed on top of the hot end (which I did).
    All credits go to the original authors !!
    Print away.................

(credits go to rmcniff)
Required Hardware:
Assembly requires the bearing and shoulder bolt from the stock extruder.
Additionally, it requires one M3 flat head cap screw per extruder, and a 0.375" X 1" or similar compression spring. I am currently using a spring from McMaster-Carr that works perfectly. It is part number 1986K5:
http://www.mcmaster.com/#1986k5/
NOTE: If your extruder clicks and does not extrude, it you likely have too much spring tension. In this case, swap the spring for a weaker or shorter one.
Printing the parts:
Print the base pieces. I used ABS with 3 shells, 0.15mm layer height, and .3 density supports and "doSupportUnderBridges": true. It helps to print both the left and the right at the same time so that the details of the smaller top come out better
Print the arm pieces. I used ABS with 4 shells, 0.15mm layer height, and 0.4 density supports with "doSupportUnderBridges": true to help the bridging of the guide tube hole.
print the cover pieces. I used ABS with 2 shells, 0.15mm layer height, no supports. Again, it helps to print both the left and the right pieces at the same time to allow cooling between layers
Finishing the parts:
Some post-print detailing may be required to achieve the desired tolerances and fit of components. The below is a rough guide to the drill sizes I used to finish the holes after printing. If you don't have the bits listed, any close approximation should work fine
NOTE: BOTH MOUNTING HOLES OF THE BASE PIECE HAVE 2 DIAMETERS. DO NOT DRILL OUT THE SMALLER DIAMETER OF EITHER HOLE!!!
1/4" end mill was carefully used to grind out the larger hole of the cover piece to get the arm to swing easily while assembled. Could also use a 1/4" drill bit
Number 21 drill bit (.161") was used to shape the shoulder bolt holes in the cover and arm pieces
Number 44 drill bit (.086") was used to shape the small filament guide holes in the arm and base pieces
Number 27 drill bit (.144") was used to shape the bearing peg hole in the cover piece
B or C drill bit (.238" or .242") was used to shape the filament guide tube hole
Installation
Remove the extruder stepper motor from the Makerbot gantry and remove the existing extruder assembly until you are down to the bare stepper motor
Mount ONLY the new drive block base piece to the stepper motor using the shoulder bolt and M3 screw. Install the stepper motor into the Makerbot gantry and check the alignment of the lower guide hole with the hot end entry hole (See photo). If alignment is off, you may need to re-shape the hole with a drill bit, or re-print the part scaled up to allow for part shrinkage.
Ensure that the drive gear also properly aligns with the lower guide hole. If not, loosen the grub screw and slide the drive gear to the desired position on the stepper motor shaft and re-tighten
Unmount the stepper motor again, and fully assemble the drive block as shown in the photos, using the M3 screw in the base only, and the shoulder bolt as the arm pivot through all three parts.
Re-install the stepper motor with the fully assembled drive block back into the the Makerbot gantry.
Re-connect the cooling fan and stepper motor wires
Enjoy failure-free printing!

description.header: A new version of this thing has been released.
description.text: The new version (available here) has an improved chinrest, however, you can still use this thing if you prefer.

This is my second electric violin design - the first is a 1/2 scale model and [can be found here](http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:430479 )
As with the last design, this violin's roots can be found in the excellent FFFiddle by David Perry
This violin was redesigned from scratch (again!) in Solidworks 2012 to produce a violin small enough for my 4-year-old son. This is actually the smallest instance of a design that was specifically built to be scale-able, allowing interested makers to build whatever size unit suits them best.
This "Thing" holds the STL files needed to build the 1/16 scale violin. In the future each size will have it's own Thingiverse page, and there will be an additional Thingingiverse page for the CAD models so that those who are interested can tweak the design as they wish. Anyhow, I hope you enjoy it - my son sure does!

description.header: A full range of EPV sizes are now available:
description.text:
4/4 Scale
3/4 Scale
1/2 Scale
1/4 Scale
1/8 Scale
1/16 Scale

• I printed all parts with raft, 15% infill, 4 shells. The fingerboard should be printed without support since it is difficult to remove from the long holes in the part. I used ABS, but any stiff polymer should be acceptable.

    Additional components required:

  • Schaller M6 Mini tuners (3+3)
  • K&K sound "Twin spot" piezoelectric pickup
  • 1/4" rod or tube (tube is preferred - rod will need to have a hole drilled in it)
  • Violin strings
  • 20" of music wire (0.025" - 0.035" diameter - alternatively, a ball-end violin string can be used)

    Tools:

  • Hacksaw - use this to put a slot in the end of the tube that will catch the knot in the end of the music wire
  • Small Phillips Screwdriver - for driving tuner screws
  • A variety of grits of sandpaper - used to smooth the surface of the fingerboard. A small amount of the appropriate solvent helps too.
  • 10 mm wrench - for tightening the tuner banjo nuts.
  • A triangular or knife-edge file - for making notches in the bridge and nut for strings. With care, a sharp knife can be used for this.
  • Appropriate tools for cleaning support material from prints

comments.author: mccand

comments.text: I'll definitely be posting SW files, but I have some stuff to clean up first.
comments.author: cyclone

comments.text: The 5th tuner tensions the body of the violin.  There's a music wire running from the tip of the truss rod (which is near the end of the fingerboard) down to the tuner, and counteracts the bending moment on the truss rod from the strings.  It also lets you build this unit without any fasteners!
comments.author: mccand

comments.text: Now that is a clever move. Using the tuner you bought in the set of 6. Have you noticed any instability? Is there a particular need to counteract the flex of the truss? Does it continue to bend and fall out of tune?
comments.author: mccand

comments.text: I haven't noticed any instability - the whole structure is designed to be self-aligning.  It also seems to hold its tuning pretty well.
comments.author: cyclone

comments.text: None of my F-F-Fiddles have continued to bend (since introducing the rod), and the red one has been tuned up for maybe 6-8 months now. They are more flexible than is ideal, which can make tuning a bit more iterative because as you tune one string the instrument flexes.
comments.author: mccand

comments.text: And there you have it - from someone who has far more experience with these things than I!  Thanks for chiming in, David.
comments.author: OpenFabPDX

Hi-
I designed this little thing for a project at Kishwaukee College. It's a simple, very useful bag clip. To use, just fold over the open top of your bag a couple of times and simply slip this clip over the folded edge.
This little gadget is as simple as it gets, but I find it to be very useful. I've printed and handed out dozens of these here using our uPrint SE+, and haven't recevied any complaints about it.
I'm providing an stl and a sldprt file for Solidworks if you'd like to modify the part at all.
Please let me know if you print one of these and try it out this by sending me an email at [email protected] - I'd really like to hear from unbiased people about how you find the product works for you.
Thank you!
Paul
Fold over, or twist shut the open part of a bag you'd like to be held closed, and simply slip the clip onto the bag to hold it closed. Couldn't be more simple.

Template for cutting an envelope to suit 160mm x 112mm cards. Includes slots to enable easy embossing of fold lines using a toothpick or other blunt, narrow object.
Requires a large build platform (major dimensions are 244 mm x 191 mm).
This piece was commissioned by a client (my wife) based on an envelope that she cut by hand.
For more information on using the template, see my wife's blog: http://greetingsfromgoonie.wordpress.com/2014/09/10/envelope-template/

Simply print this stencil, then use a Stanley knife / craft knife / scalpel to cut out the envelope, and use a toothpick or back of the knife to score along the fold lines (using the 2mm wide slots provided) to allow easy folding.
I recommend not using any kind of skirt/brim, etc when printing, as it may leave artifacts around the edges when removed, which will make it harder to cut smoothly around the stencil.

Botte mote is based on a mechanism made out of digitally cut 3mm dmf and small size standard recycled plastic bottles. It can be used to generate collapsible objects. The files uploaded allow the construction of protable tables in various sizes and configurations.
It has been designed to be used as an urban plug in to personalize, customize or appropriate urban space. It could be used, as well, in many other circumstances. 
The project has been developed in a cooperative process by a team composed by Isabel GonzÃ¡lez, Lucas LÃ³pez and Javier Yela with tutors Areti Nikolopoulou and Jose Perez de Lama, and with the collaboration of Susana Velasco, at \\"The commons factory :: plug ins at santa ana\\" workshop, taking place october 18-25th 2010 at Absolut Lab [Fab Lab], Madrid, Spain

Digital files are to be cut in a laser cutter in 3mm 810 x 600 mm dmf sheets. They could be cut in 3 mm plywood too. Joints in the files consider the material lost by the laser cut [Epilog Legend Ext 36x24 50 watts]. They should be tested to check if it works in the same way with the laser cutter you might be using. 
Plastic bottles [small size] have to be assembled in couples joining their bottom parts with \"bridas\", and fixing them to the dmf parts screwing the bottle cups. The structures [see images], in the proposed designs are assembled in scissor like configurations, allowing for the collapsibility of the pieces.

title: Clip Holder for Acoustic Guitar Pickup

description.text:
This is a clip for a very specific type of acoustic instrument pickup: the Oyster. The Oyster ships with a putty for attaching the pickup to the instrument. But over the years the putty hardened and fell off. This holds it in place!
I created it using the 3D modeling app for the iPad, Android Tablets, and now web browsers: http://AutodeskFormIt.com original blog post:
http://autodeskformit.com/2013/04/05/what-else-can-i-make-with-formit-3d-printing-and-other-friday-fun/

I printed it on a Replicator2 with PLA at .2 mm layer height. I think I did about 30% infill. I cut out a small piece of thin foam to place in the bottom of the pickup to act as a buffer between the pickup and the guitar. This is optional. If you would like to remix this Thing, you can grab the file from:
http://a360.co/1tHsfV0 You need to create a free Autodesk 360 account, place the file in a sub-folder called "FormIt" and then you can access it from the free FormIt iOS or Android tablet app or by visiting http://beta.autodeskformit.com to edit right in your browser!

title: Destination: You pedometer quick change clip
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a quick change clip for the pedometer provided by Global Fit's Destination:You program. Unfortunately, Global Fit's programs are only available to eligible members... from their website, "You are eligible only if your Employer, Insurance Provider, or Membership Group sponsors the GlobalFit benefit." ( http://www.globalfit.com/default.asp ) I'm posting this in case anyone else is eligible, to make sure it gets released with the right license, so I can share the design with the company and program managers. I also worked hard to develop this tab and slot connection method, to make a 100% printable design, and I hope others can learn from and improve the design. These slice and print well raftlessly. If you have difficulties with the Badge Holder or Lace Bootie, try printing these with a raft. I designed the parts for quick printing with a minimum of material and low profile, since the end product rides on top of the shoelaces in your shoe. Mix and match colors for a custom look. For best results, tabs should always be printed horizontally to eliminate stringing and improve precision. Likewise, slots should always be printed with the open side directly against the heated build platform

Print one badge holder.  Print one Lace Bootie, Back Clip, and two Lace Clips per shoe.  The Lace Bootie or Lace Clips may need to be adjusted for the shoe.  The bottom of the lace bootie should fit under the top of the shoe at the tip of the tongue.  The Lace Clips need to be short enough to fit between the Lace Bootie and tongue, and with an appropriate sized opening for the shoe laces.
Assemble the set by inserting the tabs in the front of the Badge Holder into the holes in the Lace Bootie.  The holes in the Lace Bootie might need to be reamed Slide the Back Clip along the dados in the Lace Bootie and clip it into the Badge Holder.  Using super glue, two-part plastic epoxy, or hot glue, glue the Back Clip into the Lace Bootie, then glue the two Lace Clips on top of the Lace Bootie.
After the glue dries, remove the Badge Holder.  Slip your Destination:You tracker into the Badge Holder.  Thread your first and second laces (nearest where the tongue meets the shoe - usually one straight lace and one crossed set of laces) into the lace clips.  Try to twist them so they attach the Lace Bootie firmly to your shoe, pointed straight forward.
Planned for the near future are alternate lace clips for arm and foot band usage.

title: Bold Machines: Mr. Walthersnap
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
We created a film treatment for a movie called Margo and have worked with artists to get the characters made, and are launching the concepts on a mission to explore the frontier of film-making by starting with 3D printed models.
A good story calls for a great hero like our detective Margo, but it also requires a sinister villain.
Enter Mr. Walthersnap. Everyone in Brooklyn thinks they love Mr. Walthersnap. He is a powerful businessman. Margo thinks he's great too until she smells something odd around him. Working in her lab under the Brooklyn Bridge she comes to the realization that Mr. Walthersnap is using a powerful psycho-chemical agent to make people agree with him. What other things will Margo discover about Mr. Walthersnap? Now that she's on to his tricks, she's going to uncover the rotten core under the sweet smelling exterior of Mr. Walthersnap.
As with Margo, this model was created to spec by Jose Alvas Da Silva.
Read more here on the Bold Machines Blog. https://www.boldmachines.com/blog/2014/8/16/mr-walthersnap
And if you haven't checked out Margo, go check her out! http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:456460
Print out the models and assemble according to the assembly diagrams.

author: boldmachines

title: BMW Motorcycle System Case plastic barbell strap holder

description.text: A replacement for the tiny plastic barbells that hold the elastic straps inside the BMW motorcycle System Case.

The STL file is ready for printing on a plastic extruder like a Makerbot. The bar across the middle is a hexagonal cylinder but it comes out nice and rounded when printed on a Makerbot. The model only has 18 faces so it can't get any simpler.
The openscad file gives you more options for how the barbell is modeled. You can make different versions, from the original BMW shape with hemispheres on the end to the abstracted version shown here. Some options will be more applicable to different processes. For example, maybe the rounded version would work well on a CNC lathe.

As you will read in the description of my "I Made One", I was only able to locate four hex pencils long enough to be of use in the original pencil shelf. However, I DID manage to find a stack of pencil crayons which my children had put into a throwing away box. (They reckon that they are too old for 'colouring in' any more). Hence the remix.
I have blanked off the holes which take the ends of the pencils so you will have to cut them all to the same length. Each hole is 8mm deep and there is 2mm of solid wall beneath them.
My pencils were around 7.7mm diameter and although the holes in the shelf are 8mm in diameter in my original drawing file, they shrink down when printed as described by Nophead here: http://hydraraptor.blogspot.co.uk/2011/02/polyholes.html .
(Owl print by my mate Mark Gilbert - thanks Mark)

description.text:
-------------- Feb. 6th, 2013-------------------
  • Small update*
    • Solidworks sldprt files have been uploaded for your pleasure. These have not been modified at all and reflect the stl files published earlier. Please, please keep in mind that I'm fairly new at Solidworks, and this was one of the first projects I undertook as a new user. There may be a million better ways to model these parts, but I made do with what I knew at the time. If I modify these sldprt files, I will re-upload. If you modify them and feel your design works more efficiently than this one, would you please be so kind as to send me the sldprt files you created? Just to satisfy my own curiousity - i always like to see other way of doing things - I think that makes me a better designer. My email is [email protected] Thank you! Paul

Hi-
This is my version of the Kinekt Gear Ring. This was a project I did for a class at Kishwaukee College, and I think it turned out pretty decent. It doesn't go together very easily, but as you can see from the picture, it does actually go together. I'm still working on this, and any suggestions would be very helpful. I'm not an engineer, so the tolerances are not great, please forgive me...
These files may be updated soon, as I continue to clean up the design.
The picture shown here is a real quick shot and doesn't show the gears cleaned up yet. I took an Xacto blade and carefully trimmed off the flash left over from the printing and now the gear profiles are smoother and turn much better once assembled.
This was a lot of fun or me to draw, I hope anyone who has a chance to print this gets theirs to work as well as mine now does. After use, it gets easier to spin - I think some petroleum jelly might help too with the assembly and to keep everything spinning smoothly.
If anyone's interested, here MODERATION
is a link to a youtube video I did of a similar design. this version used screws to hold the gears in place, rather than the snap in gears that evolved after some trial and error in real life. I just couldn't get the screws to print good enough at the small scale required...
Thanks for looking, sorry for the long description! Paul

Print 6 of the gear wheels, 2 of the gear meshes and 1 each of the ring top and bottom.Put gear meshes in place, snap gears into the holesand squeeze together the top and bottom ring halves.
I'm still perfecting this, so please be gentle with me if yours doesn't go together perfectly... I used a uPrint SE+ printer to print my version.
Once I get the Solidworks files to my liking, I will go ahead and upload those too, just so anyone can have the files I worked so hard at. Right now, I'd like to keep them to myself, as I'm wary of the criticism that might (rightly) come with showing my work haha....

description.text:
shiny honeycomb is a DIY lighting device made out of a laser cut structure, aluminum cooking containers that act as reflectors and standard light bulbs. The model showed here is cut in plexiglas 3mm. It could also be cut in 3mm dmf sheets. It has a modular architecture that allows for multiple configurations horizontally and vertically.
It is designed to be used as an urban plug in to personalize, customize or appropriate urban space. Ita
The project has been developed in a cooperative process by a team composed by VÃ­ctor Arranz Torrego, Paula Garcia, Laura Gonzalez Malingraux and Oscar MiguÃ©lez FernÃ¡ndez with tutors Areti Nikolopoulou and Jose Perez de Lama at \"The commons factory :: plug ins at santa ana\" workshop, taking place october 18-25th 2010 at Absolut Lab [Fab Lab], Madrid, Spain

The device is a press fit system easy to assemble. It allow for multiple configurations.
The cutting files are designed for 810 x 600 mm plexiglas sheets to be cut with a laser cutter. Joints in the files consider the material lost by the laser cut [Epilog Legend Ext 36x24 50 watts]. They should be tested to check if it works in the same way with the laser cutter you might be using. 
Aluminum containers and lighting fixtures are assembled after the structural pieces are put together.
Rhino and dxf files are cutting files. 
[We will be uploading assembly drawings in the next days]

I recently bought a Pixhawk flight controller with GPS module. The GPS module kit doesn't come with an antenna mounting system (though you can buy one separately). Thought I'd try to design something simple and replaceable myself.
This design consists of a tray for the GPS module (with a tight fit) with rubber-bound cleats and two mounting sockets (one to connect to the multi-rotor frame and the other to the GPS module tray). The top mounting socket is secured by the same rubber-band that keeps the GPS from flying out of the tray (which is topless). The bottom mounting socket can be trimmed and drilled to fit whatever you use for your multi-rotor's frame (its a solid 1mm thick plate - depending on your floor/ceiling print settings). The top and bottom mounting sockets have holes that will accomodate a standard bamboo BBQ skewer.
This is a work in progress - I've not tested the system yet and I don't know yet if it will transfer too much vibration to the GPS antenna or if it will slip causing the GPS antenna to become missaligned with the multi-rotor frame.

I printed this on a MarketBot Replicator 2 using Matterhackers Black filament at standard layer thickness (200um) at 120mm/s speed, 205 degrees C - directly on the acrylic build plate. UPDATE:
Added a specific bracket for the AnyCopter hub from Flitetest.(http://store.flitetest.com/electrohub-plates-only/) Also updated the hole diameter to better fit the BBQ Skewers I use without requiring any glue or sanding. Print 1x 3D_Robotics_GPS_Module_Mount
Print 2x 3D Robotics GPS Module Mount Shaft Cleat or if you are using the AnyCopter Electrohub Print 1x 3D_Robotics_GPS_Module_Mount
Print 1x 3D Robotics GPS Module Mount Shaft Cleat
Print 1x Anycopter GPS Mount Bracket.

description.text:
I decided I wanted to print out some mockups of the new iPhone 6, in both the 4.7" and 5.5" sizes.  
Specs were taken from the leaked Foxxcon documents.  I guessed on the corner radius, as well as the edge bevel sizes, but the length, width, and height are accurate.  
Print them off so you can see which size you like best!

This prints perfectly with the MakerBot 2, in any of the preset resolution settings.
I printed them just fine with .3mm layer height and 20% infill, 2 shells. Basically the "Low" preset, with 20% infill.

comments.text: The one labeled 4.7 is a iPhone 5 (4") and the one labeled 5.5 is a 4.7".

description.text:
Update: a dual color version is now available: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:218535 So you have opened your heart for this wonderful person. Now you can show him or her what is inside.
Here is the box to present your Valentines gift in style. The bottom and lid are bonded together so they'll never loose each other. If you cannot 3d print yourself you can buy a printed version at 3dWeeb's Etsy store (http://www.etsy.com/uk/listing/157663617/heart-box-a-3d-printed-box-perfect-for)

• Update: I made some slight changes to get an easier snap . They are in heartcontainer fdm filmhinge4.stl*
    • The bottom and lid of this heartshaped box are connected with a filmhinge so you cannot loose the lid. It snaps shut with a little twist.
    I made some slight changes to get an easier snap . They are in heartcontainer fdm filmhinge4.stl This was printed in PLA on a prusa mendel. I am very curious how this will print on other types of 3dprinters so please let me know your results.
    the size for printing is 164 x 147 x 33 mm
    The closed box is 100 x 100 x 35mm
    Sofar I have seen very nice result from makerbots even scale down to 0.6 the hinges work great. I used Slic3r with concentric infill for bottom,
    bottom layer 0,4mm
    next layers 0,3mm To get good filmhinges it will help if you have a concentric first layer infill, have a nicely printed first layer and carefully remove the print from the bed.

comments.text: This is cool.  But as a newb, I have no idea how to use it - I mean on the software/wiring side.  Does it stay on all the time, or is there a forum post that goes over the particulars?
comments.author: allanonmage

comments.text: There's connections on the board marked "fan" that you have to plug the fan into, then turn cooling on in Slic3r and set the minimum fan speed using M106 SXXX where XXX is a number between 0 and 255.  Use the lowest number where the fan reliably turns on and divide it by 255 to get your minimum fan speed as a percent.  That's it!
comments.author: allanonmage
